options.content:
The metrics for this dashboard are collected directly from the cgroupfs.

Executable snippet (extracted from [metrics.sh](https://github.tools.sap/kubernetes/connectivity-monitor/blob/master/connectivity-exporter/metrics.sh)):

```shell
cd /sys/fs/cgroup || exit 1
awk 'FILENAME == "cpuacct/cpuacct.usage"                {printf "cpu_usage_seconds_total{} %s\n", $1/1e9}
     FILENAME == "cpuacct/cpuacct.usage_percpu"         {for(i=1; i<=NF; i++)
                                                           printf "cpu_usage_seconds_total{cpu=\"%s\"} %s\n", i-1, $i/1e9}
     FILENAME == "cpu/cpu.cfs_period_us"                {printf "cpu_cfs_period_seconds{} %s\n",  $1/1e6}
     FILENAME == "cpu/cpu.cfs_quota_us"                 {printf "cpu_cfs_quota_seconds{} %s\n",   $1/1e6}
     FILENAME == "cpu/cpu.shares"                       {printf "cpu_shares{} %s\n",  $1}
     FILENAME == "cpu/cpu.stat"                         {printf "cpu_stat_%s{} %s\n", $1, $2}
     FILENAME == "memory/memory.max_usage_in_bytes"     {printf "memory_max_usage_in_bytes{} %s\n", $1}
     FILENAME == "memory/memory.usage_in_bytes"         {printf "memory_usage_in_bytes{} %s\n",     $1}
     FILENAME == "memory/memory.stat" && $1 !~ /^total/ {printf "memory_stat_%s{} %s\n", $1, $2}' \
  cpuacct/cpuacct.usage            \
  cpuacct/cpuacct.usage_percpu     \
  cpu/cpu.cfs_period_us            \
  cpu/cpu.cfs_quota_us             \
  cpu/cpu.shares                   \
  cpu/cpu.stat                     \
  memory/memory.max_usage_in_bytes \
  memory/memory.usage_in_bytes     \
  memory/memory.stat
```

Example output:

```prometheus
cpu_usage_seconds_total{} 18.4423
cpu_usage_seconds_total{cpu="0"} 11.34
cpu_usage_seconds_total{cpu="1"} 7.10226
cpu_cfs_period_seconds{} 0.1
cpu_cfs_quota_seconds{} 0.02
cpu_shares{} 204
cpu_stat_nr_periods{} 12849
cpu_stat_nr_throttled{} 155
cpu_stat_throttled_time{} 14073345361 # unit: ns
memory_max_usage_in_bytes{} 190087168
memory_usage_in_bytes{} 43745280
memory_stat_cache{} 14204928
memory_stat_rss{} 21487616
memory_stat_rss_huge{} 18874368
memory_stat_shmem{} 0
memory_stat_mapped_file{} 8650752
memory_stat_dirty{} 0
memory_stat_writeback{} 0
memory_stat_swap{} 0
memory_stat_pgpgin{} 544731
memory_stat_pgpgout{} 540592
memory_stat_pgfault{} 1268322
memory_stat_pgmajfault{} 0
memory_stat_inactive_anon{} 0
memory_stat_active_anon{} 21479424
memory_stat_inactive_file{} 14057472
memory_stat_active_file{} 405504
memory_stat_unevictable{} 0
memory_stat_hierarchical_memory_limit{} 524288000
memory_stat_hierarchical_memsw_limit{} 524288000
```

- the usage of the CPU quota and the memory limit is fairly low in the regular
  case -> maybe we could use smaller limits
  - we need to provision the CPU quota and memory limits for the high load scenario (many
    reconnects during a downtime)
  - autoscalers are not applicable for this usecase: if the api server is not
    available, they can't work and the reaction time is far too slow anyways ->
    some kind of overprovisioning is unavoidable

panels.description:
The CPU quota is enforced in each 100ms period.

Although it is not accurate, we can illustrate the CFS quota as a mCPU value. Note that on a multi-core system, the quota enforcement is more complicated than what this simple representation suggests.

I recommend reading this blog post for more details: https://engineering.indeedblog.com/blog/2019/12/unthrottled-fixing-cpu-limits-in-the-cloud/
panels.title: CPU quota

panels.description:
The CPU shares are used to assign CPU time to runnable processes during contention.

They are only used when the system is saturated.

Each runnable process gets CPU time according to ratio of its share and the sum of the shares of the runnable processes.

Processes are organised in hierarchies (cgroup) and the shares are enforced on all levels.
panels.title: CPU shares

panels.description:
`rate(nr_periods)` number of periods that any thread in the cgroup was runnable during a second

`period` length of the bandwidth control period in seconds (typically 100ms)

`rate(nr_periods) * period` the percentage of the quota enforcement periods with runnable threads from the cgroup

100% means that some of the threads were running in each period. *It does not mean that they were throttled, they might have finished their work within the available quota.*
panels.title: Used CPU quota enforcement periods

panels.description:
`rate(nr_periods)` number of periods that any thread in the cgroup was runnable in a second

`rate(nr_throttled)` number of runnable periods in which the application used its entire quota and was throttled, in a second

`rate(nr_throttled) / rate(nr_periods)` the percentage of the quota enforcement periods in a second when the threads were runnable but couldn't run because they were throttled by the CPU bandwidth control

*100% means that the application is throttled.* It used all its quota and probably would have needed (much / a bit - we can't know) more CPU time to finish its work. (Probably much higher latency)

Values below 100% mean that the application could finish its work, but needed a bit more wall clock time (hence higher latency) due to quota enforcement.

0% means that the application is not affected by quota enforcement, it could finish its work as fast as it could have finished it without quota enforcement. (same latency)
panels.title: CPU throttled quota enforcement periods

panels.description: `throttled_time` sum total amount of time individual threads within the cgroup were throttled
panels.title: Rate of CPU throttled time

panels.description:
The kubelet excludes inactive_file (i.e. # of bytes of file-backed memory on inactive LRU list) from its calculation as it assumes that memory is reclaimable under pressure.

https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/administer-cluster/out-of-resource/
panels.title: Memory usage without inactive file

panels.description:
The kubelet excludes inactive_file (i.e. # of bytes of file-backed memory on inactive LRU list) from its calculation as it assumes that memory is reclaimable under pressure.

https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/administer-cluster/out-of-resource/
panels.title: Available memory (considering inactive_file as available as well)
